SECTION 1 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



PLANT INFORMATION

Facility Name: Miramar Water Treatment Plant San Diego, CA 92131

Parent Company: City of San Diego, Public Utilities        Department    

 RMP Facility ID: 1000 0014 2909



 Submission Receipt Date: June 2017



POLICY

The City of San Diego Public Utilities Department has and continues to design facilities, operate and maintain equipment, and commit the personnel and resources to meet or exceed industry standards and regulatory requirements. The City has developed and implemented the Process Safety Management/Risk Management Prevention Program which provides a systematic approach to employee involvement, safety awareness, emergency response, risk management, and program assessment related to chlorine facilities at the plant.

PLANT DESCRIPTION

The Miramar Water Treatment Plant (WTP) was originality built in the early 1960s and treats water for the northern portion of the City of San Diego and for sale to other agencies. The Miramar Water Treatment Plant has a maximum water treatment capacity of 215 million gallons per day (MGD). The Miramar Water Treatment Plant is located adjacent to the south shore of Lake Miramar Reservoir in a predominantly residential area in the northern portion of the City of San Diego. The surrounding terrain is relatively hilly. Currently, there is a significant amount of existing residential development to the south, west, and east of the facility, and there is a significant amount of existing commercial development to the west of the facility. The Miramar WTP currently uses chlorine to disinfect water from Miramar Reservoir and the California Aqueduct, making it suitable for use in the City of San Diego's drinking water distribution system and for sale to other agencies. The chlorine is received in one-ton pressurized liquid containers at the secured Chlorine Storage Room of the Chlorine Building. The Chlorine Storage room is equipped to store a maximum inventory of

38 containers fo

r a total of approximately 76,000 lbs. of chlorine. Upgrades have been continually made in order to improve the safety of the chlorine process equipment. The most recent upgrades were implemented in 2011 (see Table 3-1 in Section 3).

COMMITMENT

The Miramar Water Treatment Plant has a well-trained and committed operations and maintenance staff with a record of over 40 years of using chlorine safely. To support the efforts of continued safe handling and use of chlorine at the Miramar Water Treatment Plant, senior management has committed to the development of a comprehensive Process Safety Management Program under the guidelines of State and Federal mandates which has

 

involved complete engineering reviews of the chlorine storage and feed system and design certification.

PROGRAM COMPLIANCE

The Risk Management Prevention and Process Safety Management Programs have been developed and implemented. The Risk Management Prevention Program is in fulfillment of the requirements of 40 CFR PART 68 within Section 112(r)(7) of the Clean Air Act and the California Accidental Release Prevention Program regulations (Title 19, Chapter 4.5 of the California Code of Regulations). The Process Safety Management Program is in fulfillment of the Occupational Safety and Health Administrations (OSHA) 1910.119, as well as Cal/OSHAs California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials.

As with the use of any hazardous chemicals, the use of chlorine in this treatment process poses the potential for an accidental release that could have offsite consequences. It is for this reason that several years ago, under the provisions of the Risk Management Program Rule (40 CFR PART 68), an assessment of potential offsite consequences of accidental release scenarios of chlorine to the surrounding environment was conducted at the Miramar Water Treatment Plant. Under the provisions of the rule, the treatment process at the Miramar Water Treat

ment Plant is considered a "Program 3" process, and as such an analysis was conducted of (1) a "worst-case" release scenario and (2) one or more alternative release scenarios. Incorporated into the Risk Management Plan (RMP) was the analysis of potential offsite consequences of an accidental chlorine release. This analysis produces information related to the residential population and public and environmental receptors which may be affected in the event of an accidental chlorine release.

SAFETY ELEMENTS

Safety elements can be defined as either administrative or engineering controls.

Administrative elements include: 1) procedural requirements, 2) training, 3) operator certification, and 4) the City's policy and commitment of resources.

Engineering elements include physical modifications of facilities to 1) detect, 2) contain, 3) treat, 4) warn, and/or 5) eliminate a potential incident. 



The following engineering upgrades were made to enhance the management and mitigation of an accidental chlorine release (see Table 3-1 in Section 3 for dates of implementation/review):



1)    Chlorine leak detection sensors were installed in the chlorine container storage building and feed system. These sensors activate alarms within the plant when low levels of chlorine are detected within the Chlorine Storage Building.

2)    A computerized process control program allows the Duty Plant Operator to see immediately from the Operations Control Room what part of the chlorine feed system is alarming, (and at what chlorine concentration) without leaving the control room.

3)    An automatic chlorine shut-off system was installed to minimize a chlorine release by enabling the operator to stop the chlorine feed at the cylinder in the event of a release.

4)    An automatic switchover system was installed, which allows for the automated switchover from the two on-line containers to the two standby containers.

 

5)    A fully enclosed building was constructed to contain chlorine vapor in the even

t of a release and eliminate free discharge to the atmosphere.

6)    A chlorine vapor scrubber system was installed in the chlorine building to neutralize chlorine vapor, preventing a release outside the building and rendering the building safe for re-entry.  The scrubber system is capable of neutralizing 2,000 lbs. of chlorine.

The following administrative safety controls have been implemented:

1)        Several safe-work-practices for the operations and maintenance sections have been developed in conjunction with other safety programs to insure employees work and respond to incidents safely. The Miramar Water Treatment Plant, in conjunction with the Public Utilities Department Emergency Management Coordinator, have developed and tested a Chlorine Emergency Response Plan. The Chlorine Emergency Response Plan was developed to support the Water Plant staff in the event of a chlorine release in which additional resources are required to mitigate the situation. The San Diego Fire Department's Hazardous Materials Incident Response Team (HIRT) is dedicated to respond to the plant in the event of an incident which exceeds the response capabilities of the plant staff. The Miramar Water Treatment Plant maintains a Business Plan that identifies evacuation points on the site and provides additional emergency information about chlorine and additional contacts if needed. All personnel assigned to this site are trained and certified on the provisions of this Business Plan.

ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidental releases of the regulated substance at the Miramar Water Treatment Plant in the past 5 years that have resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.





COMPLIANCE AUDIT

A Process Safety Management (PSM) compliance audit was conducted by the Department's Production Engineering Team and the Plant's senior management in January of 2017

in accordance with applicable Cal-OSHA regulations, specifically Paragraph (0), 8 CCR, ? 5189 of Cal-OSHA. The purpose of the audit was to evaluate the adequacy of the PSM and RMP programs and provide recommendations for improvements as needed. The Audit Report is included in the Appendix of the RMP.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The City of San Diego has trained and certified all plant staff to the level of first responder. Additional support will be provided by the San Diego Fire Department's Hazardous Materials Incident Response Team (HIRT). In the event HIRT is required, plant staff can mobilize all necessary resources with a single radio or telephone call. In addition, an automated dialing system has been installed. This system automatically contacts relevant responders (HIRT and/or plant staff) in the event that a chlorine concentration threshold is detected by the gas sensors in the Chlorine Room. All relevant design and operations of chlorine facilities at Miramar WTP have received thorough review by the Fire Department

 

prior the construction or implementation. Fire Department staff have worked closely with plant staff to develop a thorough familiarity with the operation of chlorine facilities in order to facilitate efficient emergency response.

PLANNED CHANGES

The Miramar Water Treatment Plant has received numerous engineering upgrades throughout the last decade. Facilities installed recently or currently in construction including:

1.    Installation of an automatic paging system for critical alarms (complete).

2.    Installation of a notification system for 'man down' scenarios (complete).

3.    The replacement of the two clearwells (construction is underway).

The City of San Diego Public Utilities Department and the Miramar Plant staff are committed to providing 'state of the art facilities that produce high quality drinking water while protecting the environment and the health and safety of plant staff and the public.
